Home.intro: This is my portfolio site where I share technical learning and experiments. A place to output daily technical insights and contribute to the tech community through new technology validation, experimental feature implementation, and knowledge sharing.

metadata.description: Portfolio site for technical learning and knowledge sharing. Featuring portfolio content and experimental labs.
metadata.title: Satoshi Ogura

Home.portfolioDescription: Information about the site author and creator
Home.sourceCodeDescription: The source code for this portfolio site is publicly available on GitHub.
Home.title: Welcome to o3osatoshi portfolio

education.tokyo: The University of Tokyo, Graduate School of Frontier Sciences

experience.napierDescription: Built V2 web frontend for an EVM DeFi protocol, largely solo. Tech: TypeScript, Next.js, Tailwind, wagmi, viem, GraphQL, Zod, Neverthrow, Vercel, Sentry.
experience.salonDescription: Built a CRM 0→1 across frontend/backend. Tech: TypeScript, Next.js, Tailwind, Express, Firebase.
experience.softbankPmDescription: Gateway design bridging consortium chain and legacy payments.
experience.softbankResearchDescription: Researched corporate Web3 strategy (Uniswap, AA, contract wallets), delivered POCs and internal reports.

PortfolioAbout.intro: Full-stack engineer. I work across Web3 (DeFi, Solidity, wagmi/viem) and Web2 (CRM, Firebase, Express). I care about type safety, tests, CI/CD, and clean UX. Recently supported an EVM-based DeFi protocol frontend from zero to $40M+ TVL.

metadata.description: Full-stack engineer specializing in Next.js, TypeScript, and Web3/DeFi. Focused on type safety, testing, and CI/CD.
metadata.title: About — Satoshi Ogura

skills.backendItems: Node.js, Express, Prisma, PostgreSQL, Firebase, AWS, Docker, Vercel
skills.qualityItems: Zod, Neverthrow, Jest/Playwright, Sentry, Turborepo, GitHub Actions, Figma

RedisCacheDemo.description: Call a deliberately slow API endpoint (<endpoint>/edge/public/heavy</endpoint>) via the interface service and cache the result in Redis. Subsequent requests within the TTL should be served from cache and return much faster.
RedisCacheDemo.title: Redis cache demo

SleepDemo.description: Simulate a cancellable pause that rejects with an infrastructure error when aborted.
SleepDemo.title: Sleep helper demo

ToolkitAsynchronous.intro: Explore helpers for cancellable timers and infrastructure-friendly error handling. The example below shows how <sleep>sleep</sleep> produces an Infra-layer error when aborted.

metadata.description: Demonstration of the cancellable sleep helper from @o3osatoshi/toolkit.
metadata.title: Toolkit · Asynchronous utilities

ToolkitAsynchronous.sectionIntro: Start the demo to run a three-second delay. Abort the operation to see the helper reject with an <infraError>InfraCanceledError</infraError> that preserves the abort reason.
ToolkitAsynchronous.title: Asynchronous utilities

ToolkitIndex.intro: Shared utilities from <toolkit>@o3osatoshi/toolkit</toolkit> can be explored here. Browse the sections below for interactive demos and usage patterns.

metadata.description: Index of shared toolkit examples for the o3osatoshi portfolio project.
metadata.title: Toolkit

ToolkitIndex.redisCacheLink: Redis cache: speeding up a slow API with Upstash
ToolkitIndex.title: Toolkit examples

ToolkitRedisCache.intro: This demo calls a deliberately slow API endpoint exposed by the interface service at <endpoint>/edge/public/heavy</endpoint> and uses the Upstash cache adapter from <integrations>@repo/integrations</integrations> to cache the response. Requests within the TTL are served from cache; once the TTL expires, the next request recomputes the value by hitting the slow API again.

metadata.description: Demonstration of using the Upstash cache adapter from @repo/integrations to cache a slow API response.
metadata.title: Toolkit · Redis cache

ToolkitRedisCache.sectionIntro: Press the button below multiple times. The first request should take roughly three seconds as it hits the slow API. Subsequent requests within the cache TTL will be significantly faster and marked as "Redis cache"; after the TTL expires, the next request will become slow again and refresh the cached value.
ToolkitRedisCache.title: Redis cache
